tn.text: The mother of King Manasseh (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The nominal adjective "evil" can be translated as a relative clause "things that ... evil." Here Yahweh's "sight" refers to how he judges or decides on the value of something. Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "things that Yahweh said were evil" or "the things that Yahweh considers evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Another possible meaning is "including the disgusting things."
"Manasseh rebuilt"
The story of King Manasseh's reign continues.

tn.ref: It is in Jerusalem that my name will be forever.
tn.text: The name is a metonym for the person. AT: "Jerusalem is where I will forever make known who I am." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: He built altars for all the stars of heaven in the two courtyards of the house of Yahweh
tn.text: It is implied that he built these altars so people could make sacrifices and worship the stars. AT: "He built altars in the two courtyards of the house of Yahweh so that the people could worship the stars and offer them sacrifices" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: He put his son into the fire
tn.text: You may need to make explicit why he put his son in the fire and what happened after he did so. AT: "He burned his son to death as an offering to his gods." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"asked for information from"

tn.ref: evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The nominal adjective "evil" can be translated as a relative clause "things that ... evil." Here Yahweh's "sight" refers to how he judges or decides on the value of something. Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "He did things that Yahweh said were evil" or "He did the things that Yahweh considers evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The story of King Manasseh's reign continues.
Manasseh probably did not do the work. His servants would have done the work. AT: "that Manasseh had ordered his servants to make" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: that I will put my name forever
tn.text: "where I want people to worship me forever" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The feet are a synecdoche for the person, and the name of the people group is a synecdoche for the people themselves. AT: "the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: even more than the nations that Yahweh had destroyed before the people of Israel
tn.text: Here "nations" refers to the people who had lived in the land of Canaan before the Israelites had arrived. AT: "even more than the people whom Yahweh had destroyed as the people of Israel advanced through the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: idols," therefore Yahweh, the God of Israel, says, "Look
tn.text: This translation understands the words "therefore ... says" to be those of the prophet. Another possible meaning is that Yahweh refers to himself as if he were another person: "idols. Therefore Yahweh, the God of Israel, says, 'Look ... tingle."

tn.ref: whoever hears of it, both his ears will tingle
tn.text: The physical feeling is a metonym for the emotional feeling that causes it. AT: "those who hear what Yahweh does, will be shocked." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line used against Samaria, and the plumb line used against the house of Ahab
tn.text: The words "measuring line" and "plumb line" are metaphors for the standards Yahweh uses to judge people. AT: "judge Jerusalem using the same measure I used when I judged Samaria and the house of Ahab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Samaria is the capital city and it represents all the people of the kingdom of Israel. AT: "against the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
a tool made of a heavy weight and a thin rope used to show if a wall is straight
Here "house" represents family. AT: "the family of Ahab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"I will abandon" (UDB) or "I will reject"

tn.ref: give them into the hand of their enemies
tn.text: "let their enemies defeat them and take over their land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"Also" or "In addition"

The words "shed much innocent blood" are a metonym for killing people violently. It might be best to translate this so the reader understands that other people helped Manasseh do this. AT: "Manasseh ordered his soldiers to kill many innocent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he had filled Jerusalem from one end to another with death
tn.text: This hyperbole emphasizes the great number of people Manasseh had killed throughout Jerusalem. The abstract noun "death" can be stated as "dead people." AT: "there were very many dead people throughout Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The nominal adjective "evil" can be translated as a relative clause "things that ... evil." Here Yahweh's "sight" refers to how he judges or decides on the value of something. Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "things that Yahweh said were evil" or "the things that Yahweh considers evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This can be expressed in active form and assumes that the answer is positive. The question is rhetorical and is used for emphasis. See how this phrase is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:08:22|8:23]]. AT: "they are written ... Judah." or "you can find them ... Judah." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a polite way of saying he "died, as his ancestors had, and" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Possible meanings are 1) "the garden that had once belonged to a man named Uzza" or 2) "Uzza Garden." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is a man's name (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: followed in all the way that his father had walked in
tn.text: "walked in all the ways that his father walked in." The way a person lives is spoken of as if that person were walking on a path. AT: "lived completely the way his father had lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"He went away from Yahweh" or "He paid no more attention to Yahweh"
"made plans and worked together to harm him"
This is a generalization. AT: "some of the people in Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"made plans and worked together to harm." Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:21:21|21:23]].

AT: "they are written ... Judah." or "you can find them ... Judah." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
